chapter.title: Installation of the Mobicents Converged Application Server
chapter.para: The Mobicents Converged Application Server can be installed by downloading the ready-to-go binary distribution, or, alterately, the source code can be obtained using the Subversion version control system (VCS) and then built from source. Installing the binary distribution is recommended for most users, and obtaining and building the source code distribution is recommended for those who want access to the latest revisions and capabilities.

section.title: Binary Distribution: Installing, Configuring and Running
section.para: The Mobicents Converged Application Server runs on top of the JBoss Application Server. The Mobicents 1.20 binary distribution comes bundled with the JBoss Application Server version 4.2.2 GA.

section.title: Pre-Install Requirements and Prerequisites
section.para: You should ensure a few requirements have been met before continuing with the install.

listitem.para: You must have sufficient disk space in order to install the Mobicents binary release. Once unzipped, version 1.20 (BETA3) of the Mobicents binary release requires about 150 MB of free disk space. Keep in mind that disk space requirements may change from release to release.

varlistentry.term: Anything Java Itself Will Run On

listitem.para: Both the Mobicents Converged Application Server and the JBoss Application Server are 100% Java. Mobicents will run on the same hardware that the JBoss Application Server runs on.

A working installation of the Java Development Kit (JDK) version 5 or higher is required in order to run the Mobicents Converged Application Server. Note that the JBoss Application Server is a runtime dependency of Mobicents and, as mentioned, comes bundled with the binary distribution.

section.title: Downloading
section.para: Download the latest version of the Mobicents binary distribution and, preferably, validate it.

step.para: The latest version of the binary distribution can be found by going to the Mobicents project page on SourceForge.net, clicking on Download Mobicents, and then looking for Mobicents Server and Latest Version. This document is written using version the Mobicents binary version 1.20 BETA3.

Verify the integrity of the zip file. Along with the zip file there is a sha1 file
For the Mobicents 1.20 (BETA3) binary release, the relevant file names are mobicents-all-1_2_0_BETA3.zip and mobicents-all-1_2_0_BETA3.zip.sha1.asc. which contains a checksum that can be used to verify the integrity of the zip file, and can alert you if the file has been changed since it was uploaded, or if it was corrupted upon download.
On a Linux system you can use the sha1sum command to verify the integrity of the binary distribution zip file.
On a Windows system you will need to download a sha1sum-generating program such as the sha1sum.exe program. This will generate a checksum that you can compare with the sum in the sha1 file.
Note that if the two checksums are not identical, it means that the downloaded zip file was corrupted upon download, or has been changed since it was last uploaded to the server.

section.title: Installing
section.para: Once the preconditions and requirements have been met, and you have downloaded the Mobicents binary distribution, you are ready to install it. Simply decompress the downloaded archive to a location of your choice, thus completing the install.

section.title: Source Distribution: Installing, Configuring and Running
section.para: The Mobicents source code is also available from the project's Subversion repository; it is possible and often suggested to install the Mobicents Converged Application Server from source. There are several reasons why you might choose to do so:

listitem.para: to learn more about the Mobicents project's directory structure structure and Maven-based build system;
for faster access to new features, such as the latest versions of the resource adapters, bundled servers, and examples;
to access extra documentation included in the source directories; and/or
to obtain proper debugging support.

section.title: Before You Begin: Mobicents Subversion Repository Directory Structure
section.para: Before proceeding with the installation, it will prove useful to examine the Mobicents project Subversion directory structure.

When downloading and building Mobicents from source, we are only concerned with all the files and directories located in and under the trunk directory. In the following sections, we will create a local Subversion repository for only the source code and files we need access to, by performing a svn checkout on the Mobicents trunk directory. But first, let's examine the contents and structure of trunk in more detail.

formalpara.para: The Mobicents Subversion repository is logically laid out. The top-level trunk directory merely contains five subdirectories: docs, parent, release, server and tools. The docs directory contains the source files for this Guide, while additional, supplementary documentation can be located in README and other text files in various subdirectories.

formalpara.title: trunk/servers
formalpara.para: The servers directory contains all of the important files for running the various servers that ship with the Mobicents Converged Application Server, including the Mobicents JAIN SLEE core, the Mobicents Media Server, and the SIP Servlets and SIP Presence Servers.

The source code for the Mobicents JAIN SLEE server and other Mobicents project servers (currently the SIP Presence Server, SIP Servlets Server, and Mobicents Media Server) lives, naturally, in the servers subdirectory of trunk.

section.para: Because we are currently concerned with installing and working with the Mobicents JAIN SLEE server, it is helpful to take a look in the servers/jain-slee directory, which contains a pom.xml build file, used for building the JAIN SLEE server, as well as the following subdirectories:

listitem.para: This directory contains the core code, build, JAR and resource files necessary for running the Mobicents JAIN SLEE server.

This directory contains all of the necessary build files for running any of the many examples that the Mobicents Converged Application Server ships with. For information on installing and running specific examples, see .

The release directory contains a readme.txt file which provides general information on the specific Mobicents release (much of which is contained in this guide), as well as various configuration files.

The resources directory contains the code and resource and build files necessary to run all of the many Mobicents resource adatpers. For information on deploying and undeploying resource adapters using the Mobicents Management Console, command line, or by copying and deleting files, see . For information about specific resource adapters, see .

The tools subdirectory of the jain-slee directory contains the resources necessary for running the Mobicents Management Console and command line interface. You probably won't need to worry about this directory.

formalpara.para: A final directory which is interesting for us is the tools subdirectory of the top-level trunk directory, which contains the source code for the Mobicents Eclipse IDE plugin, SIP Balancer application, and various quality assurance tools (the QA directory).

section.title: Pre-Install Requirements and Prerequisites

listitem.para: You must have sufficient disk space in order to install the Mobicents source as well as the JBoss binary distribution. The Mobicents source, once fetched from the development Subversion repository, consumes about 250-300 MB of disk space. In addition to this, the JBoss Application Server binary distribution (version 4.2.2 GA), once decompressed, requires approximately 115 MB, meaning that you should probably have at least 415 MB of free disk space available. Keep in mind also that disk space requirements will change with subsequent updates to the development repository.

varlistentry.term: Anything Java Itself Will Run On

listitem.para: Both the Mobicents Converged Application Server and the JBoss Application Server are 100% Java. Mobicents will run on the same hardware that the JBoss Application Server runs on.
A working installation of Java 5 or higher is required in order to run Mobicents and the JBoss Application Server.
A way to download files is required. We will use the wget utility in the subsequent sections, but any common web browser will suffice.

varlistentry.term: The Subversion Version Control System or Client

listitem.para: The Subversion Version Control System (VCS) is required in order to check out the latest Mobicents source code. In addition to the command line client, there are a number of other clients that can be downloaded or installed via your package manager:

formalpara.title: Basic Subversion (the shell client)
formalpara.para: If you are reasonably proficient on the command line, this is the only client you will need. You can get a binary version for your operating system here: . Note that I will be using the command line (shell) Subversion client throughout this Guide.

formalpara.title: The Meld Diff, Merge and Graphical VCS Tool
formalpara.para: On Linux and UNIX-based operating systems, Meld is the Swiss Army knife of version control tools (VCSes). It can do 2- and 3-way diffs between files, diffs between directory hierarchies, and also serves as a graphical VCS front-end for the Subversion Version Control System, as well as Git, Darcs, Mercurial, Bazaar(-NG), Monotone, Perforce and CVS, among possible others. Note that you also need the basic Subversion shell client installed before Meld can function with it. Meld is available from .

note.para: Both the Ant and Maven build tools are required in order to build the Mobicents Converged Application Server and deploy resource adapters, etc.
